body:
## Problem

Can't easily show an animated "spinner" in statusline.

## Expected behavior

1. provide `vim.iter.cycle()` (do this first, before the next items)
    - generates a result each time it is called, so for example can be used to animate from a series of chars like `⠋ ⠙ ⠹ ⠸ ⠼ ⠴ ⠦ ⠧ ⠇ ⠏`
    - open questions: what about the "timer" aspect?
        - start by providing sample code
        - see if we need `vim.ui.spinner()` or some other abstraction
2. if needed after `vim.iter.cycle`, provide higher-level interface like `vim.ui.spinner()` which has a default spinner animation `⠋ ⠙ ⠹ ⠸ ⠼ ⠴ ⠦ ⠧ ⠇ ⠏`
    - uses `vim.iter.cycle()` internally
    - open question: If `vim.ui.spinner()` is a generator/coroutine, it will "just work" every time statusline is refreshed, but will look random because the "refresh rate" of 'statusline' is not fixed.

## Open questions

- is there existing precedent for animating a statusline? requires setting the "refresh rate" of statusline.

comment_data.body: This could maybe be something like a `vim.iter.cycle({"⠋", ...})` to create an infinite iterator where one gets the `next` on each refresh. At least that's how I do spinners in other languages.

> Provide something like vim.ui.spinner() which generates an animation frame each time it is called, using chars like ⠋ ⠙ ⠹ ⠸ ⠼ ⠴ ⠦ ⠧ ⠇ ⠏.

Need to keep in mind if there is more than one spinner in use at one time. Creating an iterator makes more sense with this considered.

Timing of the delay between the steps can also be useful, as it allows adjusting different type of easing (like "slow start, quick end", etc.). So maybe somehow baking in time delays might be useful.

Maybe something like this:

```lua
--- @class vim.ui.SpinnerStep
--- @field char string Character to be displayed as snipper step.
--- @field delay integer Amount of milliseconds to show this step (i.e. wait
---   before showing next step).

--- @class vim.ui.SpinnerOpts
--- @field reverse boolean Whether to reverse from last to first before repeating a cycle.

--- @class vim.ui.Spinner
--- @field start fun(self: vim.ui.Spinner) Start spinner.
--- @field stop fun(self: vim.ui.Spinner) Stop spinner.

--- @param steps vim.ui.SpinnerStep[]
--- @param opts vim.ui.SpinnerOpts
--- @param on_step fun(char: string, char_id: integer) Callback to be executed
---   on every step update. Can include forcing `vim.cmd.redrawstatus()`, etc.
--- @return vim.ui.Spinner
function vim.ui.spinner(steps, opts, on_step)
  -- TODO
end
```

I hope this api to exist under (or at least highly integrated with) `vim.ui.progress` mentioned in #32537 so that we can have more generalized progress indicator methods with spinner provided as a first-party style.

I got curious to see how it might look like to have a spinner hard coded only in default statusline, but still have customizable shape (number of steps, text and delay of each step). Here is [the result](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34493#issuecomment-3001204986) (posted originally in PR for 'busy' option as implementation is hard coded towards the "show spinner if 'busy' option is more than 0" assumption).

At the moment I'd say it is possible to have a relatively concise implementation of a spinner in default statusline without any of `vim.iter.cycle()` and `vim.ui.spinner()`. Maybe re-framing the design to only have user-customizable spinner shape (as a global list option, for example) and delegating everything else spinner-related to implementations?

> it will "just work" every time statusline is refreshed, but will look random because the "refresh rate" of 'statusline' is not fixed.

I have the impression that this is a bit the elephant of the room that needs discussion.

There can be different triggers for statusline updates (E.g. there are examples like `autocmd LspProgress * redrawstatus` in the docs.)

The problem is that with each additional trigger, the refresh rate increases. Which would make a spinner go faster. But worse - for cases like consuming progress messages, it will cycle through them more quickly, making it more difficult to read them before they disappear.

One way to deal with that could be to:

- Ensure the statusline is redrawn at least with a given rate (and additional triggers get smoothed out somehow?)
- Have a function/component that allows to adjust the updates bases on the current refresh rate, to have it decoupled from ^ similar to how in games one no longer moves faster just because you have more FPS. This could be decoupled from a spinner and applicable to any kind of queue-of-things which one might want to consume at a given rate. Like progress messages

> * Ensure the statusline is redrawn at least with a given rate (and additional triggers get smoothed out somehow?

The previously [linked implementation](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34493#issuecomment-3001204986) of the default statusline component (that is intended to show spinner only if 'busy' is positive) does not depend how many progress updates there are. Each progress update might (or might not) increase the buffer's 'busy' number which only affects how long the spinner will be spinning.

> At the moment I'd say it is possible to have a relatively concise implementation of a spinner in default statusline without any of `vim.iter.cycle()` and `vim.ui.spinner()`

That's a great reference point! Though imo the code clearly shows why it's non-trivial and worth having cycle()/etc.

As far as an implementation of `cycle()`, I'm assuming we'll want to try to implement all/some of the base methods of `Iter`.

But I would categorize them roughly into three buckets:
#### has (mostly) well defined behavior
- `next`
- `peek`
- `rev` (some wiggle room for exact behavior)
- `take`
- `skip`
- `nth`
- `map`
- `enumerate`

#### plausible but needs care
- `find`
- `any`
- `all`
- `filter`
 
if predicate never triggers, will loop forever

#### questionable
- `each`
- `join`
- `slice`
- `rpeek` 
- `pop`
- `rskip`
- `rfind`
- `last`
- `totable`
- `flatten`

these can work if used with `take`. or we can choose to operate over the initially passed in list. we can also just choose to not implementation all of these.

## Define 3 Layers

- **Spinner Layer**: Displays spinner characters.
- **Driver Layer**: The driver that starts/stops/refreshes the spinner, such as `LspProgress`, asynchronous tasks like `vim.system()`, etc.
- **UI Layer**: The place where the spinner is displayed, such as `statusline`, `tabline`, etc.

## Who Drives Next Frame: Spinner or Driver?

From the perspective of the UI layer, a spinner frame is just a **read-only** character.

1. If driven by the **Driver**, we need to consider the frequency/frame rate of the Driver:
   a. Some drivers do not have progress capabilities and only have start/stop events, such as `one-shot` jobs.
   b. The progress of a **Driver** is random, so a compatibility layer is needed to wrap it for stable spinner display.
    ```lua
    vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("LspProgress", {
     callback = function()
         -- get next frame
         local ch = vim.iter.cycle(chars)
     end,
    })
    ```
    **Drivers** like `LspProgress` have progress notification capabilities and can drive the next frame by subscribing to `LspProgress`, but one-shot asynchronous tasks do not.
2. If the **Spinner** itself drives the next frame, the **Spinner** only needs to provide `start()` + `stop()` APIs.
   This offers higher scalability and allows spinners to be displayed for all asynchronous tasks.
   For example:
   a. call `spinner:start()` when initiating requests like `lsp_diagnostic` or `lsp_goto_definition`,
   b. call `spinner:stop()` after job done.

**Conclusion**
Having the **Spinner** drive the next frame itself provides better encapsulation, clearer semantics, and stronger scalability.

## Who Refreshes the UI: Spinner or Driver?

Spinners can be displayed in the following locations, each with different refresh methods and **none** refresh automatically:

| UI           | show                                     | refresh                              |
| ------------ | ---------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------ |
| statusline   | `set statusline="%!v:lua.spinner()"`     | `:redrawstatus` or `nvim__redraw()`  |
| tabline      | `set tabline="%!v:lua.spinner()"`        | `:redrawtabline` or `nvim__redraw()` |
| statuscolumn | `set statuscolumn=..`                    | `redraw` or `nvim__redraw()`         |
| extmarks     | `nvim_buf_set_extmark()`                 | `nvim_buf_set_extmark()`             |
| floatwindow  | `nvim_open_win() + nvim_buf_set_lines()` | `nvim_buf_set_lines()`               |

Displaying spinners in UIS requires some configuration code.

If the **Driver** refreshes the **UI**, we facing the same issues of frequency/frame rate and who drives the next frame.
Since frame rate/frequency information is encapsulated within the **Spinner**, the Spinner should be responsible for refreshing the UI.

For example, `spinner:start()` can accept a callback `on_step` executed when when the spinner drives the next frame, then updates the **UI**.

```lua
local sp = vim.ui.spinner()
local on_step = function()
    vim.cmd("redrawstatus") -- refresh statusline
end
sp:start(on_step)
```

## Is the Frame Rate of the Spinner Fixed?

I prefer Yes.

1. A **Spinner** is just a simple presence/absence indicator; the speed of its refresh has little significance.
   As mentioned above, perform a spinner with "slow start, quick end" —-- than can be done and looks nice, but it’s probably unnecessary.
2. In general, a Driver's progress events are triggered randomly with no fixed frequency.
   Therefore, we need to apply `debounce/throttle` to events for smooth refreshing.
   Refreshing too fast consumes resources (UI refresh is time-consuming after all), while refreshing too slow is meaningless or even causes lag.

## Is a Generator vim.iter.cycle() Needed?

`vim.iter.cycle()` is optional; it does not block the implementation of `vim.ui.spinner()`.

Combining our conclusions:

1. The **Spinner** drives the next frame.
2. The **Spinner** has a fixed refresh frequency.
3. The **Spinner** refresh UIs.
   It’s easy to see that we can implement this using `vim.uv.timer`:

```lua
local chars = { "⠋", "⠙", "⠹", "⠸", "⠼", "⠴", "⠦", "⠧", "⠇", "⠏" }
timer:start(0, interval, function()
    local frame = vim.iter.cycle(chars)
end)
-- or without vim.iter.cycle()
local idx = 0
local chars = {...}
timer:start(0, interval, function()
    idx = (idx % #chars) + 1
    local frame = chars[idx]
end)
```

## Proposal

```lua
---@class vim.ui.spinner
---@field start fun(self: vim.ui.spinner, on_step?: function) start spinner
---@field stop fun(self: vim.ui.spinner) stop spinner
---@field __tostring fun(self: vim.ui.spinner): string
---
---@class vim.ui.spinner.Opts
---@field chars? string[] spinner chars.
---@field interval? integer refresh interval, milliseconds.
---@field ttl? integer the spinner will automatically stop after {ttl} milliseconds.

---Create a spinner.
---
---@param opts?: vim.ui.spinner.Opts
---@return vim.ui.spinner
vim.ui.spinner = function(opts) end
```

A example show how to add lsp progress spinner to statusline:

```lua
--- Not a very good practice, just for demonstration purposes.
local lsp_sp = vim.ui.spinner()
function lsp_sp_component()
	return tostring(lsp_sp)
end
vim.o.statusline = vim.o.statusline .. "%!v:lua.lsp_sp_component()"
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("LspProgress", {
	callback = function(event)
		local kind = event.data.params.value.kind
		if kind == "begin" then
			lsp_sp:start(function()
				vim.cmd("redrawstatus")
			end)
		end
		if kind == "end" then
			lsp_sp:stop()
			vim.cmd("redrawstatus")
		end
	end,
})
```

## Open Question

Should we encapsulate implementations for several commonly used spinner UIs ? For example, a `CursorSpinner`, which would allow displaying a spinner near the cursor during various LSP operations like `lsp_diagnostic` or `lsp_goto_definition` (I really want to do this).

I created a simple proof-of-concept project: [https://github.com/xieyonn/spinner.nvim](https://github.com/xieyonn/spinner.nvim)
Here's a preview of a slightly more complex example showing a spinner next to the cursor

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6bf01d5b-cee1-493d-be4b-fddd6822e461)

## Proposal2

The Spinner module created by `vim.ui.spinner()` encapsulates:

- All frames used for display (texts)
- Display current frame (text)
- Updates and refresh rate control

The parts that need to be customized are:

- Where the spinner is displayed
  out of this module.
- How the spinner is refreshed
  By providing an `on_change` callback when creating the **Spinner**.

```lua
---@class vim.ui.Spinner
---@field start fun(self: vim.ui.Spinner) start spinner.
---@field stop fun(self: vim.ui.Spinner) stop spinner.
---@field __tostring fun(self: vim.ui.Spinner): string show current spinner frame.

---@class vim.ui.SpinnerEvent
---@field text string current spinner frame, empty means spinner stopped.

---@class vim.ui.SpinnerOpts
---@field texts? string[] spinner frames.
---@field interval? integer refresh interval, milliseconds.
---@field ttl? integer the spinner will automatically stop after {ttl} milliseconds.
---@field initial_delay? integer start spinner after {initial_delay} milliseconds.
---@field on_change? fun(event: vim.ui.SpinnerEvent) called when spinner start/refresh/stop, used to
---         refresh UI component

---Create a spinner.
---
---@param opts?: vim.ui.SpinnerOpts
---@return vim.ui.Spinner
vim.ui.spinner = function(opts) end
```

Add lsp progress spinner in statusline:

```lua
local lsp_sp = vim.ui.spinner({
	on_change = function(event)
		vim.cmd("redrawstatus")
	end,
})
function lsp_sp_component()
	return tostring(lsp_sp)
end
vim.o.statusline = vim.o.statusline .. "%!v:lua.lsp_sp_component()"
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("LspProgress", {
	callback = function(event)
		local kind = event.data.params.value.kind
		if kind == "begin" then
			lsp_sp:start()
		end
		if kind == "end" then
			lsp_sp:stop()
		end
	end,
})
```

add lsp progress in a floating win next to cursor:

```lua
local win
local buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)
local lsp_sp
local on_change = function(event)
	local text = event.text
	if text ~= "" then
		if not win or not vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(selfwin) then
			-- create window
			win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, false, {
				relative = "cursor",
				--- ... other necessary options
			})
		end
		vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(self.buf, 0, -1, false, { tostring(lsp_sp) })
		return
	end

	-- close window
	if win ~= nil and vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win) then
		vim.api.nvim_win_close(win, true)
	end
end

local lsp_sp = vim.ui.spinner({
	on_change = on_change,
})

-- subscribe to LspProgress
lsp_sp:start()
```

I came up with a new idea: 

if we has a **N:1** relationship between drivers and a spinner, then stopping the spinner should only happen after **all drivers** have called `spinner:stop()`.  
To support this, `start` and `stop` should accept a `from` field to identify the source.
```lua
local sp = vim.ui.spinner()
sp:stop("lsp_progress")
sp:stop("lsp_diagnostic")
```

Or more simply, there’s no need to track from here—just maintain an internal `count`: start +1, and stop -1, stop only `count == 0`
